properties.description: The American Revolution (1765–1783) as an ideological and political movement
American Revolutionary War launched in Battles of Lexington and Concord
Second Continental Congress formed the Continental Army and appointed George Washington commander-in-chief
Declaration of Independence unanimously adopted by Second Continental Congress
Decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown
Treaty of Paris signed, codifying US independence and granting territory
Establishment of the sovereign United States of America
Discontent with colonial rule began shortly after the defeat of France in the French and Indian War
British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs and turned control of western lands to British officials
Representatives from several colonies convened the Stamp Act Congress
Declaration of Rights and Grievances argued 'taxation without representation violated their rights'
British Parliament's passage of the Townshend Acts
King George III deployed British troops to Boston
British troops killed protesters in the Boston Massacre
Anti-tax demonstrators destroyed the Royal Navy customs schooner Gaspee
Sons of Liberty activists instigated the Boston Tea Party
London responded by closing Boston Harbor and enacting a series of punitive laws (Intolerable Acts)
First Continental Congress convened, coordinating Patriot resistance
Patriots in control in every colony after British withdrawal from Boston
King George III proclaimed Massachusetts to be in a state of open defiance and rebellion
Second Continental Congress passed the Lee Resolution, affirming support for national independence
France entered the Revolutionary War, supporting the colonial cause
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs under salutary neglect
English Civil War (1642–1651) and its aftermath
King Philip's War (1675–1678) fought without English military assistance
Charles II and James II attempted to bring New England under direct English control
Consolidation of New England colonies, New York, and New Jersey into Dominion of New England
English aristocracy removed James II from power in the Glorious Revolution
Boston revolt which overthrew Dominion rule
William and Mary granted new charters to individual New England colonies, restoring local democratic self-government
Parliament passed the first in a series of Navigation Acts, restricting colonial trade
Molasses Act 1733 placed a duty on foreign molasses imported into the colonies
British government ceased Molasses Act enforcement efforts
French and Indian War
Bute ministry decided to permanently garrison 10,000 soldiers in North America
Native Americans launched Pontiac's War
Grenville ministry issued the Royal Proclamation of 1763, designating Indian Reserve
Parliament passed the Sugar Act, decreasing duties but stricter enforcement
Grenville proposed direct taxes on the colonies to raise revenue
Parliament passed the Stamp Act, imposing direct taxes for the first time
Sons of Liberty formed and used public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence
Boycott on imports of all British merchandise organized by Stamp Act Congress
Stamp Act repealed by Parliament
Declaratory Act of March 1766, asserting Parliament's full power
Assembly of Massachusetts Bay Colony issued a circular letter urging coordinated resistance
Governor dissolved the Massachusetts assembly for refusing to rescind the letter
Riot broke out in Boston over the seizure of the sloop Liberty
British deployed troops to Boston due to unrest
Parliament reactivated the Treason Act 1543, threatening trials in England
Most Townshend duties repealed, except the tax on tea
Private letters of Massachusetts Governor Hutchinson and Lt. Governor Oliver published
Samuel Adams created new Committees of Correspondence, linking Patriots
Parliament passed the Tea Act, lowering price of taxed tea but bypassing merchants
British government passed the Intolerable Acts
Massachusetts patriots issued Suffolk Resolves and formed Provincial Congress
First Continental Congress called for a boycott of all British goods
Washington and the Continental Army responded to Lexington and Concord by surrounding Boston
British forced to withdraw from Boston by sea

properties.name: Colonial Separatist Leaders
properties.intentions: Initially sought incremental autonomy, then full independence
properties.beliefs: Necessity of prevailing in Revolutionary War for independence

properties.name: Second Continental Congress
properties.intentions: Forming army, declaring independence, establishing self-governing rule of law

properties.name: British Parliament
properties.beliefs: Supreme lawmaking authority, entitled to levy taxes without colonial approval
properties.constraints: Political unacceptability of standing army in peacetime Britain

properties.name: George Grenville
properties.intentions: Address national debt, make colonies pay troop costs

properties.name: Sons of Liberty
properties.intentions: Ensure British tax laws became unenforceable, instigate resistance

properties.name: John Dickinson
properties.beliefs: Taxation without representation violated rights, Townshend Acts unconstitutional

properties.name: Samuel Adams
properties.role: Radical Patriot, leader of Committees of Correspondence
properties.intentions: Agitate for resistance, create rebel government framework

properties.name: Thomas Hutchinson
properties.beliefs: Colonists could not enjoy all English liberties
properties.constraints: Refused to yield to pressure from demonstrators

properties.name: Andrew Oliver
properties.intentions: Direct payment of colonial officials to reduce colonial influence

properties.name: Thomas Jefferson
properties.role: Primary author of Declaration of Independence, Committee of Correspondence member

properties.name: First Continental Congress
properties.intentions: Deliberation and collective action against British policies

properties.description: Taxation without representation violated rights as Englishmen
Parliament at Westminster saw itself as the supreme lawmaking authority throughout the Empire and entitled to levy any tax without colonial approval
Colonists effectively enjoyed 'virtual representation' in Parliament (British argument)
The economic impact of British mercantilist policies was minimal on colonists
The political friction triggered by British acts was more serious than their economic impact, especially among politically active merchants
The purpose of the Townshend Acts was to raise revenue, not merely regulate trade
Hutchinson/Oliver letters were evidence of a systematic plot against American rights
Republicanism as political philosophy best suited to American conditions, rejecting monarchy and aristocracy
Initial colonial discontent and demands for autonomy escalated to a full-blown independence movement and war due to British punitive measures and colonial coordinated resistance.

British post-war fiscal needs led to imposition of new taxes, which, when perceived as violating 'no taxation without representation' principle, generated colonial resentment and organized opposition.
British attempts to exert direct control over colonial governance (e.g., Dominion of New England) met with fierce colonial resistance, reinforcing their desire for self-governance.

The establishment of inter-colonial communication networks (e.g., Committees of Correspondence) facilitated the coordination and mobilization of Patriot resistance, providing a framework for rebel government.

Decisive military victories by the Continental Army, particularly with French support, inflicted enough cost and political pressure on Britain to compel them to negotiate an end to colonial rule and acknowledge independence.
Economic interests of merchants were the primary driver of colonial opposition, rather than ideological grievances.
key_predictions: Colonial objections would primarily focus on the burden of taxes, not representation
Merchant resistance would be stronger and more consistent than general colonial unrest

properties.description: British policy of salutary neglect, allowing colonies self-governance
British government's policy of mercantilism, colonies existing for mother country's economic benefit
Significant growth of British national debt after French and Indian War
Stationing a standing army in Great Britain during peacetime was politically unacceptable
Unwritten British constitution with guarantees of rights of Englishmen, serving as model for colonial governments
Radical Whig ideology profoundly influenced American political philosophy with its love of liberty and opposition to tyrannical government
British government lacked the resources and information needed to control the colonies effectively
Discontent with colonial rule began shortly after the defeat of France in the French and Indian War in 1763.
British Parliament imposed new taxes to compensate for wartime costs and turned control of western lands over to British officials in Montreal.
The Stamp Act Congress's 'Declaration of Rights and Grievances' argued that taxation without representation violated their rights as Englishmen.
Sons of Liberty formed and began using public demonstrations, boycotts, and threats of violence to ensure that the British tax laws became unenforceable.
Widespread descriptions of the Boston Massacre quickly began to turn colonial sentiment against the British, accelerating the downward spiral in relationship.
The Boston Tea Party was a seminal event in the American Revolution's escalation.
London's response (closing Boston Harbor, punitive laws) effectively ended self-government in Massachusetts but also served to expand and intensify the revolutionary cause.
The First Continental Congress began coordinating Patriot resistance through underground networks of committees.
The Battles of Lexington and Concord launched the American Revolutionary War.
A decisive victory by Washington and the Continental Army in the Siege of Yorktown inspired King George III and the British to negotiate an end to colonial rule.
Colonists became accustomed to running their own affairs under salutary neglect.
Capt. Levi Preston's quote: '…we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn’t mean we should.'
In King Philip's War (1675–1678), New England colonies fought Native American tribes without military assistance from England, contributing to a unique American identity.
Dominion rule triggered bitter resentment throughout New England due to restricted assemblies, new taxes, and abridged rights.
The 1689 Boston revolt overthrew Dominion rule, and colonial governments reasserted control.
Parliament passed the first in a series of Navigation Acts (1651), which restricted colonial trade with foreign countries.
The Molasses Act 1733 was protested by New England colonists as 'taxation without representation'.
Some argue that the economic impact of mercantilist policies was minimal on the colonists.
The political friction that the acts triggered was more serious, as the merchants most directly affected were also the most politically active.
'The need for money played a part in every important decision made by Grenville regarding the colonies—and for that matter by the ministries that followed up to 1776.'
Colonists objected to their lack of representation in Parliament, which gave them no voice concerning legislation that affected them, such as the tax, violating the unwritten English constitution.
Declaratory Act insisted that Parliament retained full power to make laws for the colonies 'in all cases whatsoever'.
John Dickinson argued against the constitutionality of the Townshend Acts because their purpose was to raise revenue and not to regulate trade.
The Hutchinson/Oliver letters' contents were used as evidence of a systematic plot against American rights, discrediting Hutchinson.
Committees of Correspondence linked Patriots in all 13 colonies and eventually provided the framework for a rebel government.
The Tea Act was opposed by those who resisted the taxes and also by smugglers who stood to lose business.
The British government responded by passing four laws that came to be known as the Intolerable Acts, further darkening colonial opinion towards England.
For the first time, the Patriots were armed and unified against Parliament due to coordinated resistance and militias.
The Declaration of Independence embodied the political philosophies of liberalism and republicanism, rejected monarchy and aristocracy, and proclaimed 'all men are created equal'.
Siege of Yorktown led to the collapse of King George's control of Parliament and consensus that the war should be ended on American terms.
About 60,000 Loyalists migrated to other British territories in Canada and elsewhere, but the great majority remained in the United States.

properties.reasoning: Highlights ideological objection over purely economic.
Directly states primary objection was lack of representation, not just tax amount.
The text explicitly states 'some argue that the economic impact was minimal... but the political friction that the acts triggered was more serious.'
The act itself triggered the protest.
The passage of the act was the context for the objection.
The act itself states this power.
The acts were the subject of Dickinson's argument.
The publication was the event that made the letters evidence.
The act was the cause of the opposition.
The passage of these acts directly led to the darkening of opinion.
The Declaration itself is the primary source for its content.
The outcome of the battle directly caused the political shift.
